Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grant for the 2018 Empirical Software Engineering International Week

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The grant supports travel for graduate students to attend the 2018 Empirical Software Engineering International Week, an international event, which this year will take place during October 2018 in Finland. It consists of several co-located events: Annual meeting of the International Software Engineering Research Network (ISERN); International Doctoral Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering (IDoESE); International Advanced School on Empirical Software Engineering (IASESE); the International Conference on Predictive Models and Data Analytics in Software Engineering (PROMISE).

This activity advances the field of Software Engineering through the exchange of information and collaborations. The field is growing rapidly due to the emergence of big data code repositories, which enables empirical research. The goal is to enable the research that will improve software engineering productivity and quality, while encouraging students to pursue a research career. The international dimension of the conference helps develop a globally-aware workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• This project provided funding for six (6) graduate students and one (1) early career researcher to defray travel costs (transportation, lodging, registration fees) of attending events during the 2018 Empirical Software Engineering International Week (ESEIW) in Oulu, Finland occurring October 10-12, 2018. This annual event brings together researchers from academia and industry to present their work. Attendees have the opportunity to discuss empirical research design, empirical research techniques. In addition, attendees have informal opportunities to learn from each other as they share their experiences “in the trenches” of conducting empirical research in various environments.

The grant recipients participated in some of the following events associated with ESEIW.

  • The International Doctoral Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering (IDoESE) - provides a supportive setting for PhD students to present their own research and obtain feedback from an internationally recognized panel of senior experts in empirical software engineering.
  • The International Advanced School on Empirical Software Engineering (IASESE) - provides in-depth training on the topic of Empirical Software Engineering and Data Science: Old Wine in a New Bottle. The growth of data science makes this topic particularly relevant for grant recipients.
  • The International Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering (ESEM) - is the premier international conference on empirical software engineering research. The conference provides attendees the opportunity to interact with researchers from universities and companies around the world to discuss research ideas.

Following are quotes from recipients on the benefits they gained from attending ESEIW:

  • “From attending IASESE, I gained a better understanding of the relationship between empirical software engineering and data science, as well as a valuable overview of data science techniques being used in empirical software engineering. From attending the ESEM main conference, I gained interesting perspectives and discussion on a number of topics in empirical software engineering.”
  • “First, I talked to a couple of researchers who I met at ICSE we had a chat during lunch to catch up with our research interests and discuss issues on our phd programs. Second, I also talked other professors and researchers who also worked on mining software repositories and user review analysis. I asked them a couple of questions on how to solve the problems i am currently facing with my research. Second, Many presentations were interesting. Although they were not directly related to my research, I got a couple of ideas that i plan to incorporate into my study.”
  • “I gained three primary benefits from attending the ESEIW events. The first professional gain is concerned with networking and building a larger collaboration space. During the ESEIW events I interacted with my research peers as much as I could, at coffee breaks during the conference as well as at dinner and social events outside of the conference. These interactions helped to spread my credibility as a younger researcher, as well build relationships that can turn into collaborative research efforts in the future. The second professional gain is concerned with the content of presentations. Most of the sessions I attended featured research that is very similar to my own, and I took value from the methodologies and results of such talks. I feel that I will be able to perform and present my research with higher quality after seeing these talks. The third gain I experienced as a result of attending ESEIW is a renewed vigor for my research. The research process can, at times, be demoralizing because of lack of results or reviewer feedback, and attending ESEIW supplied me with a renewed effort to perform good quality software engineering research.”
  • “I think one great benefit is meeting with peers (other Ph.D. students) and researchers from related areas and be aware of the methods and approaches to empirical research they are using.”
  • “By attending IASESE, I'm able to understand a general process of doing empirical studies in software engineering areas and how it's related to big data/data analysis concepts and techniques. There are a few specific studies introduced under those concepts during the school, which are especially interesting and inspiring as well. Also, by attending ESEM conference, I got to understand the empirical studies of different interesting topics and know about their experimental and validation methods, which are very helpful for my own studies.”
  • “I received constructive feedback from IDoESE chairs over how to solve my dissertation problem. Next ESEM event was fruitful as well as i get to talk with people who work in my area of research interests.”
